newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico's Cetes rates rise across the yield curve.
newsitem.headline: Mexico's Cetes rates rise across the yield curve.

text.p: Mexico's primary Cetes rates rose across the yield curve on Tuesday for the first time in two weeks on early jitters in the peso and rising U.S. long-bond yields.
The bellwether 28-day Cetes rate rose 24 basis points to 18.31 percent at Banco de Mexico's primary auction on Tuesday.
Analysts said they were not concerned about the slight increase in the Cetes yields, though.
"On the 28-day paper, we are not worried about it, since we believed that last week the rates were close to their short-term floor," said Santander economist Enrique Ramirez.
Analysts said the upcoming mid-term elections in Mexico on July 6 could be an additional factor adding pressure on rates.
In the secondary market on Tuesday, overnight Cetes rates rose a sharp 140 basis points to close at 18.50 percent.
Secondary rates came under pressure from an early weakness in the peso and the U.S. 30-year Treasury bond. That bond ended the day to yield 7.03 percent.
The peso recovered later in the day to end firm, but the markets had already sent a signal to investors to push rates up slightly.
The increase in the 28-day Cetes rate was more or less in line with analysts' expectations.
A Reuters' survey of nine Cetes dealers found expectations of an increase of 12 basis points to 18.19 percent on the one-month paper, and small increases across the yield curve.
The range was unusually wide on the forecasts, however, ranging from a decline of 27 basis points to a rise of 50 basis points.
A survey by MMS International also found a wide range of expectations, with the one-month paper coming in between 17.80 percent and 18.25 percent.
The one-month paper rates had fallen at the last two actions as the U.S. Federal Reserve kept its key federal funds rate unchanged.
Inflation is widely seen as coming in under one percent in May, after posting a 0.48 percent increase in the first two weeks of the month. And that may help rates to fall in the future.
"The results suggest further declines in nominal Cetes rates in the weeks ahead as real rates remain a relatively high 7.0 percent," market analysis firm IDEA said in a recent report.
